title: Millennials: Go ahead and take that vacation instead of paying off your student debt.
text:
Within days of getting engaged, my husband and I opened our first joint account. It was a savings account we nicknamed "Honeymoon July 2019" and we eagerly and diligently put money into it each month.

To some people, our choice might seem extravagant. We’re a millennial couple and like many in our cohort, student loans are a scary line item on our marital ledger.

The decision to take a honeymoon, even while paying off debt, didn’t faze me at first. I'm a personal finance author, and my husband and I decided very consciously that travel (actual personal travel, not just going to other people’s weddings) is a financial priority in our lives. Besides, we had decided to delay the trip to better align with our 2019 schedules.

Then, after more than a year of saving up for our blissful getaway, I did the math and panicked.

After getting married, we’d been aggressively paying off my husband’s student debt with our combined incomes, paying nearly four times the monthly minimum payment each month. We also had socked away monthly sums in our honeymoon fund. The way the timelines were playing out, our honeymoon savings could pay off the remaining student debt within the first year of our marriage, leaving us debt-free.

The realization put me into a tailspin, because what kind of personal finance author would I be if we went on a fancy honeymoon instead of paying off the remainder of my husband’s student debt?

The danger of black-and-white

So much of prevailing rhetoric in the personal finance industry demonizes all forms of debt and has turned it into a morality issue. But there’s a fundamental problem with telling people to eschew all of life’s luxuries (big or small) in the quest to be debt-free.

“Because crash diets end at the buffet line,” says H. Jude Boudreaux, CFP, partner and senior financial planner at The Planning Center. He thinks the black-and-white argument of denying yourself breaks while paying off debt is a false choice.

“I think the negatives stack up more than the interest,” Boudreaux says. “I think you can have a balanced way of looking at the things ...We can build a strategy that might take a couple more years and cost us a bit more in interest, but is much more do-able from a life standpoint.”

It’s also much easier to proclaim a one-size-fits-all financial mandate when you aren’t taking a holistic view of someone’s everyday life.

“I don’t know how many personal finance gurus also work with clients one-on-one and look at all of their goals and look at their budget and help them weigh the pros and cons,” says Pamela Capalad, founder and financial planner of Brunch & Budget. “There is no absolute right or wrong when it comes to things that pay down debt.”

Financial therapist Amanda Clayman acknowledges we need to be aware of the financial consequences of our decisions. But she also points out that our goal as humans isn’t just to optimize our financial lives.

“People live in a fantasy and are projecting that everything in their lives will be right when certain financial conditions are met,” she says.

When I looked at our savings and goals, the numbers told me to ditch the honeymoon and become debt-free. My emotions said otherwise.

The right emotional choice

So we took our honeymoon. I saw the thousands of dollars spent on a two-week trip together as an investment in our relationship.

Hokey as it sounds, we desperately needed time to reconnect after what our first year of marriage had served up: the death of our first dog, the adoption of a second, a move, the release of my second book and a nine-city book tour that took over six weeks, and my husband picking up every overtime possibility that he could.

On our honeymoon we put away our laptops, cell phones and work obligations and focused on each other.

Using our honeymoon fund to pay off the student loan debt would’ve only moved up our debt freedom timeline by about eight months. I’m able to sleep well at night knowing the interest that will accrue during those eight months will be money well spent: It's a down payment on a strong foundation for our marriage.

Erin Lowry is the author of "Broke Millennial Takes On Investing" and "Broke Millennial: Stop Scraping By and Get Your Financial Life Together."
